and exquisite personation of JULIA, will shortly repeat the character

B

nAY JIlai.lACi A
THEATRE.

TO THE PUBLIC.
It is a duty 1 feel I owe to the numerous portion
of the Public who have supported me in my Dramatic
efforts, briefly to explain the supposed cause of the
opposition manifested against me, and also the Character and pretensions of my Opponents. The cause
originates, I presume, in a belief that I am still con.
nected w ith the Public Press; this is not the case, as
my connection with every kind of Newspaper property
ceased as far back as Nov., 1843. I submit that the
Character and Pretensions of my Opponents may be
judged of by the fact of the following Persons having
appeared most conspicuous as Leaders of the Oppo.
sition against me, and that they have taken an
ungenerous advantage of the known defenceless
position that an Actor is placed in when on the Stage,
to attack me, leaving out of the question the right
that every Man has to claim, as I do, the-old English
privilege of—"A clear stage and no favor/'
JORN BEL ASCO, Brother to the Pugilist
The Count de WUITS- Ex-Equerry to the Duke
of Brunswick
GOODERED, of the Piccadilly Saloon
A LBERT SMITH, Writer for the Periodical Press
WILXVIOT a Brighton Coachman
PHILLIPSON better known as J a c k Phiilipson
BURTON, the Governess advertizing individual
MORRIS BARNET. a Theatrical Reporter and
Actor
HICKS alias OT W A Y, a n ' Eminent Tragedian"
CROFT the Keeper of a Gambling House
THEOPHILUS EOHALAZ describing himself as
of the Stock Exchange
Lieut. PHILIP KEMP. 9th Lancers.

B. GREGORY.
N.B.——On reference to the Worship Street Police
Report, in this Day's Papers, the public mind will
be satisfied of the Un-English and Cowardly Com.
bination formed against me.
21st of August, 1846.
S, 6, F.irt>r.tlw, Printer, 31, Bow 8tr««t, Cores. G.rd...

NOTICE
TO THE PUBLIC
B-BH-IRRRRRRR-R----

I lay market Theatre*
2lst. Aug. 1846.
Mr. DAVIDSON
conceives some explanation*
due to the Public, for the performances of Mr*
GREGOR Y being prematurely brought to a close.
On the Gth of Aug. (inst.) Mr. BEJYJAMIJY
WEBSTER
executed an Agreement to Let the House from the I O I A of the
present to the 5tA of the following Month, it being understood
at the time that it was for Mr. GREGORY to appear in some of
Shakspere's Characters, and in A N E W T P L A Y which is
now and has been for the last Week in active preparation for
production on Monday next. On Thursday Evening, after the
performance of The M e r c h a n t o f V e n i c e ,
Mr.WEBSTER*
by his Agent, communicated to Mr. DA V1DSOJY and Mr,
GREGORY that, under a pretext suggested, as U was understood
by two of Mr. GREGORY'S
opponents, he had not the power^
by his Lease, to Under-let the property, and the performance*
must be discontinued.
In this situation, Mr. DA VIDSON, the
servants,(asWardrobe-keepers,Property-men,
Carpenters, Sceneshifters, Box-keepers, Sfc.fyc.)being in the employ of Mr„
WEBSTER,
and for whose services a consideration was acknowledged in the Rent, has no present alternative but to submit
to Mr. WEBSTER'S
repudiation of his own written Engagement.
Mr. DA VIDSON can only express his extreme regret thml
through Aim, influenced by circumstances over which he ttsfortunately has no control, the Public should experience dismjp.
pointment, and he cannot but consider that any circumstaneem
which tend to keep from the Stage an Actor of the great onaf*
unparalleled powers of Mr. GREGORY,
is a public lorn; the
more so a* that loss is likely to result through the instrumentality
of a few mistaken individuals and their hireling emmissariemz
in proof of which the Public have only to refer to the PkNkw
Reports of this day.
9 0 , P«irbret.ert4lVialef, SI, §.W S—.i Covenl O.fden.

TIMES.
The production of a new five-act comedy look, like business—Haymarket
business, making one feel that the theatrical season has set in, and that
hard work is beginning. Of all productions the five-act prose comedy is
the most difficult to survey. The merit of the piece lies in the freshness
and cheerfulness with which the subject is treated. There is little or no
repartee, properly so called, but the language Hows on smoothly and naturally, and the characters speak out for themselve. with much force. The
comic speeches are written in evident good humor; the serious declamations
arc not overstrained. Novelty is shewn in the characters themselves ; there
is a reality in their discourse that declares them not to be copies. Altogether
the piece is very amusing and agreeable, and it warms and pleases by its
geniality. The acting was unexceptionable. The success of the piece was
as unequivocal as loud and continued plaudit, could make it.
